choices.D: Only data where the error field is present and does not contain a value will be displayed.
choices.B: Only data that does not contain the error field will be displayed.
choices.C: Only data with a value in the field error will be displayed.
choices.A: Only data where the value of the field error does not equal an asterisk (*) will be displayed.

questions.question_text:
What is the result of the following search?
index=myindex source=c:\mydata.txt NOT error=*

discussion.content: The search index=myindex source=c:\mydata.txt NOT error=* will return events from the "myindex" index, where the source is "c:\mydata.txt" and the "error" field is not present. The "NOT error=*" condition filters out events that have any value in the "error" field, leaving only events that do not contain the "error" field.

choices.B: Real-time searches happen instantly, while relative searches happen at a scheduled time.
choices.C: Real-time represents events that have happened in a set time window, while relative will display results from a rolling time window.
choices.D: Real-time searches run constantly in the background, while relative searches only run when certain criteria are met.
choices.A: Real-time searches display results from a rolling time window, while relative searches display results from a set length of time.

questions.question_text: When refining search results, what is the difference in the time picker between real-time and relative time ranges?

A SOC manager is complaining that a scheduled alert for failed login attempts triggered 150 emails. They still want to be alerted of failed logins via email, but they want less volume of alerts. Which of the following would resolve this for the SOC manager?

discussion.content:

fck u its C

c is correct

Selected Answer: C
C is correct. You change the alert frequency.

Selected Answer: C
Running more frequently would not decrease the emails. C is the correct answer.

choices.A: Change the schedule so the alert runs more frequently.
choices.D: Change the alert action from email to webhook.
choices.C: Change the trigger from "For each result" to "Once''.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Power
The Power role is a built-in role in Splunk that includes the minimum set of permissions needed to create, edit, and delete alerts, as well as perform other administrative tasks in Splunk. This role provides users with the necessary permissions to perform alert-related tasks without providing them with full administrative access to the Splunk instance.

Selected Answer: C
